awd_titl_txt: Self Assembly and Controlled Folding of Emulsion Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract
Traditionally, assembly lines to build machines, from electronic circuits to motor vehicles, follow very specific instruction manuals, followed by robots or people. On the other hand, in biology, organisms self-assemble spontaneously according to the instructions encoded in their genes - following the laws of physics. Inspired by biology, this project embellishes microscopic oil droplets with specific DNA interactions that guide their spontaneous assembly into complex, 3D architectures. These structures range from unusual crystals to helices with exciting optical properties due to their interaction with light. These droplets can readily be solidified, therefore they offer a route to programmable, hands-off manufacturing, with high yield of the desired material. The project aims to explain on a fundamental level the principles of organization that led to life, and this simple model system will be used as an educational tool on the mobile labs of the Biobus, both as an experimental demonstration and as a thought experiment.

Technical Abstract
The objective of this proposal is to use biological molecules, particularly lipids and DNA strands, to functionalize emulsions in order to self-assemble arbitrarily designed structures, which can readily be solidified. This versatile system allows us to control the fluidity, specificity, valency, and logical programming of interactions between droplets, which in turn facilitates the assembly of complex structures, including emulsion polymers, loops and folded configurations. In this project, we propose 1) to use multiple flavors of DNA grafted on emulsions to program the structure of matter on the micro-scale, 2) to study the folding dynamics of the pathways in search of organizing principles and 3) to use the assembled components for further assembly into large-scale materials. This 'beads-on-a-string' experimental model is analogous to protein folding on the molecular scale, but provides visual access to the chain dynamics as it folds. A major goal of this project is to integrate science education and research within the laboratory and beyond. Apart from training high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students that participate in the research, the PI participates in the World Science Festival and is a founding member of a science education facility called the Biobase, which provides school students from all socioeconomic backgrounds with a research grade microscopy facility for standards-aligned school day field trips and summer camp programs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our work demonstrates that colloidal droplets can be self-assembled into polymers (colloidomers) by specific DNA interactions. Because the droplets have liquid interfaces, where the DNA is free to move, these colloidal polymers are free to rearrange (they are freely-jointed) and therefore display the same dynamics as molecular polymers.

Just like polymers can fold into proteins in biology, these colloidal droplet chains can fold into predesigned structures (foldamers) with 100% yield, following programmed DNA interactions. In fact, theory predicts that the simplest alphabet with only two alternating letters (ABABAB…) can select a dozen foldamers (out of ~1000 possible folds) by optimizing the order of their interactions. Experimentally, we show that this is indeed possible. 

Sequence-encoding shapes opens the field of materials self-assembly to far-reaching goals. Large foldamers that contain holes, similar to napkin rings, offer exciting transport properties. Starting with a mixture of foldamers of different shapes, we show that one can design supracolloidal interactions to make mosaic tilings, or self-limiting architectures. These bio-inspired materials are reconfigurable and adaptive to the environment because the droplet-droplet DNA bonds can be triggered to exchange partners, cleave, or strengthen. 

On the fundamental level, our minimal model system allows for the exploration of questions about the underlying principles of folding. Looking at successful folders, we learn that their mechanisms are general – they undergo a core collapse or geometric frustration on the way to their folded state, each of which is a well-known phenomenon in protein folding. The methods we have developed can in principle be applied to systems with any underlying dynamics, from molecular polymers, up to macroscopic folding toys or Rubik’s snakes. 

 


Last Modified: 07/26/2022
Modified by: Jasna Brujic
